Important broad survey/expansion on how "bridging" can enable design of "social" media to be more pro-social, less anti-social - via @lukethorburn.com, Aviv Ovadya for @knightcolumbia.org @knightcolumbia. Excellent compendium of references (including by me on how bridging + middleware can synergize)

value.text:
Our paper on *bridging systems* has just been published by @knightcolumbia.org! Joint work with Aviv Ovadya, it gives a framework for translating offline peacebuilding practices into algorithmic settings. Lots of examples + open questions.

knightcolumbia.org/content/brid...

The deeper message: Don't have your AI agent call me -- I will have my AI agent call your AI agent.
Why not have our own personal agents, to manage interactions with all other AI agents?
www.nytimes.com/2023/10/16/t...

New summary of this suggested architecture, addressing @daphnek.bsky.social's issues and @ethanz.bsky.social and @chandrn.bsky.social's article, on how and why contextual privacy can be achieved, in Tech Policy Press today:
techpolicy.press/how-third-pa...

A level-headed approach to solving the privacy issues with middleware or interoperability. This is the biggest gating issue for changes to our tech ecosystem that could be profoundly game-changing. A workable privacy approach to interoperability would be a HUGE step forward.

external.title: A Better Approach to Privacy for Third-Party Social Media Tools
external.description: A robust ecosystem of third-party tools that will require fresh thinking about privacy, say Chand Rajendra-Nicolucci and Ethan Zuckerman.

She nicely delineated the "middleware" agent issues in a session with Francis Fukuyama that I moderated.
Soon after, I suggested a detailed architecture that exploits contextual privacy (before I heard the term):
ucm.teleshuttle.com/2021/11/reso...

Another Fear of Middleware? 3rd-party agents for composing social media feeds can put independent user agents between users & platforms. Some fear filter bubbles/echo chambersbut social mediation/bridging can counter that. See near end. Ties to work of many (1/2)

Wrote about what I think will be the unavoidability of using generative AI in both our work and personal lives.

For this simple reason: It really can make people more productive.

Creates a kind of communications arms race where the rest of us have to participate.

www.wsj.com/tech/ai/why-...

external.title: Why You Soon Wont Be Able to Avoid AIAt Work or At Home
external.description: Tech giants are racing to incorporate artificial intelligence into almost every aspect of their businesses, aiming to make AI indispensable for someand unavoidable for the rest of us

external.title: Why You Soon Wont Be Able to Avoid AIAt Work or At Home
external.description: Tech giants are racing to incorporate artificial intelligence into almost every aspect of their businesses, aiming to make AI indispensable for someand unavoidable for the rest of us

value.text: In news that will surprise absolutely no one (other than Elon Musk), a new study has found that if you allow hate speech on your platform, it makes your users think less of the companies who still advertise with you, harming their brands. www.techdirt.com/2023/09/14/n...

external.title: New Study: People Have A Negative View Of Advertisers Who Still Advertise On Platforms That Allow Ha...

record.text:
See my comment, plus the links from my blog post to @daphnek.bsky.social's incisive comments in the transcript of the Tech Policy Press symposium session I moderated with her, which led to the suggested solution architecture in my blog post. 
cc: @justinhendrix.bsky.social, @ethanz.bsky.social

"solving the privacy issues with middleware or interoperability...is the biggest gating issue for changes to our tech ecosystem that could be profoundly game-changing," @daphnek.bsky.social says. @ethanz.bsky.social+@chandrn.bsky.social highlight "contextual privacy." 
I had expanded on how.

value.text: A level-headed approach to solving the privacy issues with middleware or interoperability. This is the biggest gating issue for changes to our tech ecosystem that could be profoundly game-changing. A workable privacy approach to interoperability would be a HUGE step forward.

journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/...

This is horrible tragedy of zero-sum extractive thinking. User agents could manage all your watchlists, and your keep-watching stack, much like cable boxes do. A Roku exec told me the program apps refuse to allow that, just as they want to sell at "all you can eat" prices, even if not wanted.

a question for you all based on a debate ive been having in slack: Do you feel like the experience of streaming (like, cutting the cord and trying to watch stuff via the patchwork of individual subscriptions across services) is a nightmare or, generally, pretty good and abundant?
